Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Fundamental Limits of Robust Interference Management -- Between the Extremes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The capacity of wireless interference networks is one of the most important open problems of network information theory. Much progress has been made on this problem within the past decade. However, the initial focus has been on divergent extremes: where channel knowledge is available either with infinite precision or entirely absent; where the interference is either too strong or too weak; where channels are either perfectly constant or independently varying. Where previous studies have focused on extreme scenarios to arrive at radically divergent conclusions, this research reconciles the divergent extremes by resolving incompatibilities wherever they exist and exploiting synergies everywhere possible.

The research is comprised of three main components ? exploring progressively, the full range of partial channel knowledge, channel strengths, and channel coherence patterns. The stepping stones for the three thrusts include recent advances in topological interference management, the optimality of treating interference as noise, and blind interference alignment. The final critical ingredient of this research is a breakthrough in robust outer bounds, called the Aligned Image Sets (AIS) approach ? a novel combinatorial argument that bounds the relative size of the images cast by a set of codewords at different receivers based on the amount of channel knowledge available to the transmitters.

The research combines the theoretical pursuit of capacity limits with the practical concern for robustness. Understanding the capabilities of wireless communication networks in robust settings is essential for the industry, the academia, the government agencies and the society in general to have realistic expectations from the networks of the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The capacity of wireless interference networks is one of the holy grails of network information theory. Much progress has been made on this problem within the past decade by pursuing capacity approximations. However, much of the initial focus has been on extreme settings: where channel knowledge is available either with infinite precision or entirely absent; where the strength of each interferer is either comparable to desired signals or entirely negligible; where channels are either perfectly constant or independently varying. The optimistic extremes show that interference essentially is no longer an issue (e.g., everyone gets half the cake), while the pessimistic extremes find the interference barrier fundamentally insurmountable. In this project we ventured between these extremes to discover the fundamental limits of robust interference management to explore, progressively, the full range of partial channel knowledge, channel strengths, and then channel coherence patterns. Among the outcomes from this project, we introduced Aligned Image Sets (AIS) Bounds. Aligned Images bounds  are information theoretic Generalized Degrees of Freedom (GDoF) bounds that compare the entropies of different linear combinations (sums) of transmitted signals, when the combining coefficients (channels) are known to the transmitters only to finite precision. This assumption is referred to as finite precision channel state information at the transmitters (finite precision CSIT). Using AIS bounds we settled long standing conjectures on the collapse of degrees of freedom of wireless networks when the channel knowledge at the transmitters is limited to finite precision. We then  generalized the AIS approach to evaluate the benefits of partial and full transmitter cooperation. In particular we applied AIS to study the GDoF of the K user interference channel under finite precision CSIT. This is particularly significant because the AIS approach in its original form allows full cooperation among transmitters. How to apply such an approach to settings with no cooperation, such as interference channels, was a significant conceptual challenge that was solved through this project. Next, we extended the AIS approach to include not only arbitrary channel strengths but also arbitrary channel uncertainty levels and multiple antennas, especially in the context of two user MISO broadcast channels. Finally, the project culminated in a new set of sum-set inequalities  basedon AIS bounds that allow various forms of partitioning of signals by power levels, antennas, and alignment chains. These sumset inequalities provide a roadmap for further generalizations that will be essential to placing the coveted holy grail of information theory, the approximate capacity of wireless networks within reach.
